The Learning Lens: VII
A credit course on etv can seldom
be done well on a spare-time or
part-time basis. Schools and col¬
leges using etv often give faculty
members full time to prepare and
deliver three thirty-minute tele¬
vised lessons a week. The medium
demands more careful planning
and pacing. The instructor cannot
linger over the allotted period to
dwell on a point; nor can he trail off
and dismiss the class five minutes
ahead of time. One of the notable
side effects of teaching by television
is that thousands of classes are now
getting through the whole course.
Standards are similar for “the
talent” in general-audience etv.He
must be master of his subject and
skillful in its presentation. Dull¬
ness, condescension, or abstruse¬
ness are as easily escaped in etv as
in commercial television by a mer¬
ciless flick of the dial.
‘ ‘ So you see, this illustration is purely fictitious, ’ ’
Professor Crane Brinton tells his television view¬
ers, pointing to the classic Paul Revere engrav¬
ing of the Boston Massacre. “British troops would
never have formed themselves into such a close-
packed, easy target in those days when the patri¬
ots ’ favorite sport was baiting redcoats.” Brinton
goes on to describe other historically inaccurate
details of the print familiar to millions of Amer¬
icans from their history textbooks. He concludes:
“It does have value as an illustration—to show
Paul Revere’s skill as a propagandist.” Brinton’s
own illustration is part of a series called “Anat¬
omy of Revolution,” produced by WGBH-TV,
Boston, and distributed by the National Educa¬
tional Television network. The fifteen-part series
is a study of the world’s major revolutions from
the American Revolution through the Hungarian
and Cuban uprisings of the 1950s.
An admired Harvard professor, Brinton is one of
the world’s foremost historians. A Rhodes Scholar
and the author of a dozen major books, he holds
what many regard as the highest nonadministra-
tive position on the Harvard faculty, chairman of
the Society of Fellows.
This sixty-two-year-old scholar, says Robert L.
Larsen, his director for the series, “has put his
heart and soul into the television series. Despite
a reverence for the precision and power of written
language, Professor Brinton has a keen sense of
the visual aspects of his subjects. He even scrib¬
bles notes on the video side of the script. He’s
suggested illustrations we never would have
thought of.”
The respect is mutual. Of the ETV staff, Brinton
says: “ No matter how jealously a teacher guards
his subject, he will communicate it more effectively
if he puts himself in the same position with regard
to professionally skilled television people as he
would with the publisher of a book of his. Though
some of my books have had fairly wide circula¬
tion among general readers, I’ve never diluted
material in a book, nor would I in this series.”
